[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Integer Overflow] Can an attacker provide a timestamp_seconds value that when multiplied by 1000 causes integer overflow, bypassing the timestamp validity check at line 73 and allowing expired attestations? [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Timestamp Manipulation] Can an attacker provide a timestamp_seconds value close to u64::MAX such that timestamp_seconds * 1000 + ATTESTATION_VALIDITY_MS wraps around to a small value, passing the check at line 73 even with very old attestations? [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Timestamp Logic Error] Does the check at line 73 properly validate that timestamp is not in the future, or can an attacker provide a future timestamp_seconds that still satisfies the >= comparison with clock.timestamp_ms()? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Stale Attestation] Can an attacker use attestations that are exactly ATTESTATION_VALIDITY_MS (10 hours) old, potentially allowing reuse of compromised keys that have since been rotated? [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Edge Case] What happens when clock.timestamp_ms() is 0 or very small and timestamp_seconds * 1000 + ATTESTATION_VALIDITY_MS is checked - can this create an edge case allowing invalid attestations? [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Precision Loss] Does the conversion from timestamp_seconds to milliseconds (multiply by 1000) at line 73 create any precision loss scenarios that could be exploited? [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Timestamp Conversion] At line 107, timestamp_seconds is converted to milliseconds again - can inconsistent timestamp handling between validate() and actuate() create exploitable discrepancies? [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Pubkey Comparison] The check_subvec call at line 92 starts comparison from index 1 - does this skip the first byte and potentially allow pubkey substitution attacks?
